across.text: Cover for head of state overturning treaty
across.explanation: FLAT CAP(i.e. “cover for head”). Solution is FLA (i.e. “state”, specifically a recognised abbreviation of Florida) followed by PACT (i.e. “treaty”) once reversed or “overturned”, like so: FLA-TCAP.

across.text: Dives underworld figure runs guarded by animal
across.explanation: PLUTOCRAT(i.e. “Dives” – one for the theologians, this was apparently a rich man at whose gate Lazarus lay. A plutocrat, meanwhile, is a person who is powerful through their wealth. If those two sufficiently dovetail then happy days. If not, write with righteous fury to The Times). Solution is PLUTO (i.e. “underworld figure”) followed by R (a recognised abbreviation of “runs” used in a number of ball games) once placed in or “guarded by” CAT (i.e. “animal”), like so: PLUTO-C(R)AT.

across.text: Article on pop art movement
across.explanation: DADA(i.e. “art movement” of the 1920s). Solution is A (i.e. “article”, being a word like a, an or the) placed “on” or after DAD (i.e. “pop”, both words for father), like so: DAD-A.

across.text: Potentially cheater, with envy, is feeling this?
across.explanation: SEVEN-YEAR ITCH(i.e. “feeling this”, in reference to the “cheater” of the clue. The solution is a fancy for infidelity supposedly after seven years of marriage). Solution is an anagram (indicated by “potentially”) of CHEATER and ENVY IS.

across.text: Better housing one’s to throw together
across.explanation: IMPROVISE(i.e. “throw together”). Solution is IMPROVE (i.e. “better”) wrapped around or “housing” I’S (i.e. “[Roman numeral] one’s”), like so: IMPROV(I’S)E.

across.text: Country club perhaps fools around with no tension
across.explanation: UNSTRESSED(i.e. “with no tension”). Solution is UN (i.e. “country club”, specifically the United Nations) followed by DESSERTS (i.e. “perhaps fools” – other desserts are available) once reversed (indicated by “around”), like so: UN-STRESSED.

across.text: Area of science involving endless loop and geometry
across.explanation: METEOROLOGY(i.e. “area of science”). Solution is an anagram (indicated by “involving”) of LOO (i.e. “endless loop”, i.e. the word “loop” with its last letter removed) and GEOMETRY.

across.text: Don’t stick tip of spear into Josh
across.explanation: TWIST(i.e. “don’t stick”, or to draw another card in a game of blackjack or pontoon). Solution is S (i.e. “tip of spear”, i.e. the first letter of “spear”) placed “into” TWIT (i.e. “josh” – ignore the misleading capitalisation; apparently one can twit or taunt another), like so: TWI(S)T.

across.text: What musicians learn about second note in number
across.explanation: THREESCORE(i.e. “number”, specifically sixty). Solution is THE SCORE (i.e. “what musicians learn”) wrapped “about” RE (i.e. “second note” in the sol-fa notation, i.e. do-RE-me… – can be spelled re or ray), like so: TH(RE)E-SCORE.

across.text: Penning note, a manager cut further documentation
across.explanation: ANNEXE(i.e. “further documentation”). Solution is AN EXEC (i.e. “a manager” or executive) with the last letter removed (indicated by “cut”) and the remainder wrapped around or “penning” N (a recognised abbreviation of “note”), like so: AN-(N)-EXE.

across.text: This person twice burying Asian invader’s bones
across.explanation: METATARSI(i.e. “bones”). Solution is ME and I (i.e. “this person twice”, from the point of view of the setter) wrapped around or “burying” TATAR’S (i.e. “Asian invader’s”, “any of the Mongol, Turkish and other warriors who swept over Asia and Europe”(Chambers)), like so: ME-(TATAR’S)-I.

across.text: Hard worker set off to unload goods
across.explanation: TRIER(i.e. “hard worker”). Solution is TRIGGER (i.e. “set off”) with the Gs removed (indicated by “unload goods” – G being a recognised abbreviation of “good”).

across.text: Great genes uncovered of both sexes
across.explanation: EPICENE(i.e. “of both sexes”). Solution is EPIC (i.e. “great”) followed by GENES once its first and last letters have been removed (indicated by “uncovered”), like so: EPIC-ENE.

across.text: Helping to hold one after old rugby player’s seizure
across.explanation: EXPROPRIATION(i.e. “seizure” of property). Solution is RATION (i.e. serving or “helping”) wrapped around or “holding” I (i.e. “[Roman numeral] one”) and placed “after” EX (i.e. “old”) and PROP (i.e. “rugby player”), like so: (EX-PROP)-R(I)ATION.

across.text: Those with swag bag’s contents?
across.explanation: TEA LEAVES(i.e. “bag’s contents”). Clue plays on how TEA LEAF is cockney rhyming slang for “thief”, who you might stereotypically find carrying a “swag bag”. You get the idea.

across.text: Physicist entering lake in waterproof covering
across.explanation: TARPAULIN(i.e. “waterproof covering”). Solution is Wolfgang PAULI (i.e. “physicist” – no, me neither) placed in or “entering” TARN (i.e. a small mountain “lake”), like so: TAR(PAULI)N. Chalk one to my Bradford’s here.

across.text: Making uneasy old Austrian ready to accept deal?
across.explanation: SPINE-CHILLING(i.e. “making uneasy”). Solution is SCHILLING (i.e. “old Austrian ready”, or currency) wrapped around or “accepting” PINE (i.e. “deal”, specifically a board of pine that we’ve seen a few times in Jumbos now), like so: S(PINE)CHILLING.

across.text: Scholar’s problems returning after many years
across.explanation: DesideriusERASMUS(i.e. Dutch “scholar” of the 15th century). Solution is SUMS (i.e. mathematical “problems” – another we’ve seen a few times in Jumbos) reversed (indicated by “returning”) and placed “after” ERA (i.e. “many years”), like so: ERA-SMUS.

across.text: Leaves hotel to be hosted by queen, say
across.explanation: CHARD(i.e. “leaves”). Solution is H (“hotel” in the phonetic alphabet) placed in or “hosted by” CARD (i.e. “queen, say” – other playing cards are available), like so: C(H)ARD. Make easier by CHARD being part of a solution in a recent Jumbo.

across.text: One who orders programmer to engage male staff
across.explanation: COMMANDER(i.e. “one who orders”). Solution is CODER (i.e. “programmer”) wrapped around M (a recognised abbreviation of “male”) and MAN (i.e. to “staff” or provide with a worker), like so: CO(M-MAN)DER.

across.text: Learned person stayed put without vehicle
across.explanation: SAVANT(i.e. “learned person”). Solution is SAT (i.e. “stayed put”) placed around or “without” VAN (i.e. “vehicle”), like so: SA(VAN)T.

across.text: Clean items smashed in a hundred pieces
across.explanation: CENTESIMAL(i.e. “in a hundred pieces”). “Smashed” indicates anagram. Solution is an anagram of CLEAN ITEMS.

across.text: Offer to host games for baddie inAnimal Farm?
across.explanation: BIPED(i.e. “baddie inAnimal Farm“, basically the humans in the story). Solution is BID (i.e. “offer”) wrapped around or “hosting” PE (i.e. “games”, specifically Physical Education), like so: BI(PE)D.

across.text: Some power to keep ruler near throne room
across.explanation: WATER CLOSET(i.e. toilet or, playfully, “throne room”). Solution is WATT (i.e. “some power”) wrapped around or “keeping”) ER (i.e. “ruler”, specifically Elizabeth Regina) and CLOSE (i.e. “near”), like so: WAT(ER-CLOSE)T.

across.text: Preacher in say one part of church spinning record
across.explanation: EVANGELIST(i.e. “preacher”). Solution is EG (i.e. “say” or for example) and NAVE (i.e. “one part of church”) both reversed (indicated by “spinning”) and followed by LIST (i.e. “record”), like so: (EVAN-GE)-LIST.

across.text: Care to play what sounds like harsh Stradivarius?
across.explanation: RACEHORSE(i.e. “Stradivarius” – I’m not a betting man, so this needed a quick Google to confirm. I was genuinely surprised to find he’s still going strong. I was expecting him to have been some mega-famous racehorse during the 1950s or something, known today solely to the types of wrinkly old men who have every edition of Racing Post ever printed. Apparently Stradivarius won the Goodwood Cup a record four years in a row in 2020 and the Ascot Gold Cup a bunch of times. Is that enough to immortalise him? Will non-horsey types come to The Times Jumbo Cryptic Crossword Book 25 in the years to come and immediately think “ah, yes, good old Stradivarius. Bloody good horse, that…”? Hmm. We’ll see). Solution is an anagram (indicated by “to play”) of CARE followed by a homophone (indicated by “what sounds like”) of HOARSE (i.e. “harsh”), like so: RACE-HORSE.

across.text: Woman drinking beer and spirit is game for romance
across.explanation: SPIN THE BOTTLE(i.e. “game for romance” – Tsk! Bottles are for drinking, you bloody heathens. What’s wrong with Postman’s Knock? Oh, wait, that’s right, its not the 80s any more. Don’t answer that…) Solution is SHE (i.e. “woman”) wrapped around or “drinking” PINT (i.e. “beer”) and followed by BOTTLE (i.e. courage or “spirit”), like so: S(PINT)HE-BOTTLE.

across.text: Scuppered French quintet in audition?
across.explanation: SANK(i.e. “scuppered”). “In audition” indicates homophone. Solution is a homophone of CINQ (i.e. “French quintet”, i.e. the French for “five”).

across.text: Like unhealthy foods around large mouth, mostly?
across.explanation: CALORIFIC(i.e. “like unhealthy foods”). Solution is CA (i.e. “around”, specifically a recognised abbreviation of “circa”) followed by L (a recognised abbreviation of “large”) and ORIFICE (i.e. “mouth”) once its last letter has been removed (indicated by “mostly”), like so: CA-L-ORIFIC.

across.text: Performed some opera, wanting a drink
across.explanation: SANGRIA(i.e. “drink”). Solution is SANG ARIA (i.e. “performed some opera”) with one of the As removed (indicated by “wanting a”), like so: SANG-RIA.

down.text: Maiden losing heart for one of the dukes
down.explanation: FIST(i.e. “one of the dukes” – slang for one’s fists). Solution is FIRST (i.e. “maiden”) with the middle letter removed (indicated by “losing heart”).

down.text: Believer very entertained by a person putting on braces?
down.explanation: ADVENTIST(i.e. “believer”). Solution is V (a recognised abbreviation of “very”) placed in or “entertained by” A DENTIST (i.e. “a person putting on braces”), like so: A-D(V)ENTIST.

down.text: In which one’s king is in check?
down.explanation: CONSTITUTIONAL MONARCHY, “in which the power of the sovereign is defined and limited by the constitution”(Chambers), or, in other words, keeping “one’s king in check”.

down.text: Parking message again, perhaps, in dodgy grounds
down.explanation: PRETEXT(i.e. “dodgy grounds”). Solution is P (a recognised abbreviation of “parking” used in signage) followed by RE-TEXT (i.e. “message again”).

down.text: Israeli politician joining triumvirate for reform
down.explanation: PERESTROIKA(i.e. “reform” undertaken in 1980s Soviet Russia). Solution is Shimon PERES (i.e. “Israeli politician”) followed by TROIKA (i.e. “triumvirate”).

down.text: Least smart lingerie? Time to gather it up
down.explanation: UNTIDIEST(i.e. “least smart”). Solution is UNDIES (i.e. “lingerie”) and T (a recognised abbreviation of “time”) wrapped around or “gathering” IT once reversed (indicated by “up” – this being a down clue), like so: UN(TI)DIES-T.

down.text: Error of player, one who overplays old characters
down.explanation: OGHAM(i.e. “old characters”, specifically “an ancient alphabet used in Celtic and Pictish inscriptions”(Chambers)). Solution is OG (i.e. “error of player”, specifically an Own Goal) followed by HAM (i.e. “one who overplays”). One solved solely through the wordplay.

down.text: Alter view of it and repent half of errors anew
down.explanation: REINTERPRET(i.e. “alter view”). “Anew” indicates anagram. Solution is an anagram of IT, REPENT and ERR (i.e. “half of errors”, specifically the first half).

down.text: Singer grasping piano composition in class
down.explanation: TIPTOP(i.e. “class” or excellent). Solution is TIT (i.e. a songbird or “singer”) wrapped around or “grasping” P (a recognised abbreviation of “piano” used in musical lingo) and followed by OP (i.e. “composition”, specifically a recognised abbreviation of “opus”), like so: TI(P)T-OP.

down.text: Model needing to follow a diet, not half fat
down.explanation: ADIPOSE(i.e. “fat”). Solution is POSE (i.e. to “model”) placed after or “following” A and DI (i.e. “diet, not half”, specifically the first half of “diet”), like so: (A-DI)-POSE.

down.text: In one fancy net, see rising gas
down.explanation: ACETYLENE(i.e. “gas”). Solution is ACE (i.e. “one” in playing cards) followed by an anagram (indicated by “fancy”) of NET wrapped around or having “in” ELY (i.e. “see”, specifically a diocese in East Anglia that is a popular go-to for Times setters) once reversed (indicated by “rising” – this being a down clue), like so: ACE-T(YLE)NE.

down.text: Divine hosts have a clue party with nothing on is to prove a flop
down.explanation: GO DOWN LIKE A LEAD BALLOON(i.e. “prove a flop”). Solution is GODLIKE (i.e. “divine”) wrapped around or “hosting” OWN (i.e. to “have”) and followed by A, then LEAD (i.e. “clue”), then BALL (i.e. “party”), then O (i.e. “nothing”) and ON, like so: GOD(OWN)LIKE-A-LEAD-BALL-O-ON.

down.text: Art employed briefly in play’s titular event
down.explanation: TEMPEST(i.e. “play’s titular event”, referencing William Shakespeare’sThe Tempest).I’m not 100% sure about this one, but I reckon when written as TEMP EST the solution satisfies “art employed briefly”. Several setters have recently used “art” as a ye olde form of “are”, the French for which being “es” or “est”. Trouble is there is no ye olde indicator in the clue, nor a French indicator. A bit of a dog’s dinner if I’ve got this right. If I’ve not, and if some kind soul swings by with a better explanation, then I’ll update the post.

down.text: Lesbian character ill-disposed to wine
down.explanation: CHIANTI(i.e. “wine”). Solution is CHI (i.e. “Lesbian character”, basically the twenty-second letter of the Greek alphabet. Lesbos, meanwhile, is a Greek island) followed by ANTI (i.e. “ill-disposed to”). Imagine my Google search history before I twigged this one.

down.text: Mash ripe bananas – they’re heavenly!
down.explanation: SERAPHIM(i.e. “they’re heavenly”). “Bananas” indicates anagram. Solution is an anagram of MASH RIPE.

down.text: Render bucolic river with hill around it
down.explanation: RURALISE(i.e. “render bucolic”). Solution is URAL (i.e. Russian “river”) placed in or having “around it” RISE (i.e. “hill”), like so: R(URAL)ISE.

down.text: How poem ends in unbroken voice
down.explanation: ENVOI(i.e. “how poem ends”, also spelled envoy – a new one on me either way). “In” indicates the solution has been hidden in the clue, like so: BROK(EN VOI)CE.

down.text: Serving man dressing king in jacket
down.explanation: PARKA(i.e. “jacket”). Solution is PARA (i.e. “serving man”, specifically a paratrooper) wrapped around or “dressing” K (a recognised abbreviation of “king” used in chess), like so: PAR(K)A.

down.text: Sort of coffee colour seen during this month
down.explanation: INSTANT(i.e. “sort of coffee”). Solution is TAN (i.e. “colour”) placed in or “during” INST (i.e. “this month” – a shortened form of “instant” used in formal correspondence), like so: INS(TAN)T.

down.text: Effuse endlessly about a wine that’s sweet
down.explanation: SUGARED(i.e. “sweet”). Solution is GUSH (i.e. “effuse”) with the last letter removed (indicated by “endlessly”) and the remainder reversed (indicated by “about”), followed by A and RED (i.e. “wine”), like so: SUG-A-RED.

down.text: Strong metal peg left after change in America
down.explanation: NICKEL STEEL(i.e. “strong metal”). Solution is TEE (i.e. “peg”) and L (a recognised abbreviation of “left”) both placed “after” NICKELS (i.e. “change in America”), like so: NICKELS-(TEE-L).

down.text: Praising cosmetician after a make-over
down.explanation: ENCOMIASTIC(i.e. “praising”). “After a make-over” indicates anagram. Solution is an anagram of COSMETICIAN. One I remembered from the very first Times Jumbo Cryptic Crossword, which I coveredlast Christmas. Very nicely worked. Probably my favourite clue of the puzzle.

down.text: A property manager’s moving ecstasy to China, say
down.explanation: EASTWARDS(i.e. “to China, say” – other easterly destinations are available). Solution is A STEWARD’S (i.e. “a property manager’s”) with the E (street name of the drug “ecstasy”) “moved” to the beginning, like so: A-ST(E)WARD’S => (E)A-STWARD’S.

down.text: Criticise and contradict female for doubting
down.explanation: DISBELIEF(i.e. “doubting”). Solution is DIS (i.e. “criticise” – can be spelled with one or two Ss) followed by BELIE (i.e. “contradict”) and F (a recognised abbreviation of “female”).

down.text: One having an account in prose? Do badly with it
down.explanation: DEPOSITOR(i.e. “one having an account”). “Badly” indicates anagram. Solution is an anagram of PROSE DO and IT.

down.text: Two vessels touring isle that’s a sacred place
down.explanation: VATICAN(i.e. “a sacred place”). Solution is VAT and CAN (i.e. “two vessels”) wrapped around or “touring” I (a recognised abbreviation of “isle”), like so: VAT-(I)-CAN.

down.text: Three sheets to the wind on the French steamer
down.explanation: LEGLESS(i.e. pissed, or flying “three sheets to the wind”). Solution is LEG (i.e. “on” side in cricket) followed by LE (i.e. “the French”, i.e. the masculine French form of “the”) and SS (i.e. “steamer”, specifically a recognised abbreviation of “steamship”).

down.text: Like secretary’s work, dropping a line for father?
down.explanation: CLERIC(i.e. religious type or “father”). Solution is CLERICAL (i.e. “like secretary’s work”) with the A and L removed (indicated by “dropping a line” – L being a recognised abbreviation of “line”).

down.text: Stunner was a model once more, making a comeback
down.explanation: TASER(i.e. “stunner” device). Solution is RE-SAT (i.e. “was a model once more”) reversed (indicated by “making a comeback”).

down.text: Star not quite following a strict diet
down.explanation: VEGA(i.e. “star” in the constellation of Lyra). Solution is VEGAN (i.e. “following a strict diet”) with its last letter removed (indicated by “not quite”).
